intro: Rubus corylifolius var. alavensis, commonly known as the Alaván blackberry, is a variant of the evergreen bramble native to the Iberian Peninsula. It is characterized by its large, glossy, trifoliate leaves and produces dark purple to black berries. The plant thrives in temperate climates with well-drained soils and partial shade. Its botanical features include thorny stems and a compact growth habit. It is valued for its ornamental appeal and potential use in local ecosystems.
